block.p: Now that the dog days have hit, it's a good time to assess the duds in your garden -- and get rid of them.
If you love hybrid teas, replace the diseased ones with varieties that are resistant to black spot and mildew -- which may mean ordering by mail.

"Whenever I go to a nursery, I see the same roses over and over again," said Stephen Scanniello, the rosarian of the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. "Queen Elizabeth, Royal Highness, Peace. And they all get black spot. Peace is so bad, I use it as a black-spot indicator plant."

Mr. Scanniello's favorites for all-around hardiness include: Princesse de Monaco, a bicolored white-and-pink; Electron, a deep pink; Elizabeth Taylor, a two-toned pink rose that keeps blooming all summer; Sweet Surrender, a big pink rose with a spicy scent; Maid of Honor, a fragrant pale apricot; Dainty Bess, a pale pink single rose with burgundy stamens, which also blooms all summer; Gold Medal, a spicy-scented yellow grandiflora; Playboy, an orange clustered floribunda with continuous blooms that would make a good hedge. And don't forget Chrysler Imperial for the most fragrant red rose your nose will ever meet. It mildews a bit, but it's worth it.

A few mail-order nurseries are Pickering Nurseries, 670 Kingston Road (Highway 2), Pickering, Ontario L1V 1A6; Roses by Fred Edmunds, 6235 Southeast Kahle Road, Wilsonville, Ore. 97070, and Roses of Yesterday and Today, 802 Brown's Valley Road, Watsonville, Calif. 95076-0398.
